importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The mid-year report by Morningstar on the Active/Passive Barometer (June 2025) shows that only 21% of active funds outperformed passive ones over 10 years, highlighting the inefficacy of actively managed funds in market performance.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: A 10-year comparison of active vs. passive funds (through June 2025) reveals that only 21% of active strategies outperformed passive ones, indicating long-term market trends favoring passive investing.
Over a 20-year period, only 7.1% of large-cap blend funds outperformed index funds, reinforcing the idea that market outperformance is rare and passive strategies are more reliable.

keyTakeAways: The KISS (Keep It Simple and Smart) investing strategy emphasizes simplicity and low-cost index funds over complex, actively managed funds.
Most actively managed funds do not outperform index funds over the long term, with only 21% of active strategies outperforming passive ones over 10 years and just 7.1% over 20 years.
Target-date retirement funds automatically adjust asset allocation (more bonds as retirement nears), making them ideal for most individuals.
For those seeking more control, a basic portfolio of U.S. stocks, international stocks, and investment-grade bonds is recommended due to simplicity and effectiveness.
For intermediate-term goals (5–10 years), low-cost bond funds or active bond funds may offer better performance than stocks.
A simpler portfolio reduces decision fatigue, improves transparency, and makes it easier to pass on to heirs or manage during cognitive decline.
Ultimately, the best returns depend on consistent saving, not just on investment strategy.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The article by Jeanne Sahadi for CNN promotes the KISS (Keep It Simple and Smart) investing strategy, arguing that most actively managed funds fail to outperform low-cost index funds over time—only 21% of active funds outperformed passive ones over 10 years, and just 7.1% over 20 years. Experts like Amy Arnott of Morningstar emphasize that simplicity reduces decision fatigue, improves transparency, and ensures easier portfolio management—especially during retirement or cognitive decline. The article recommends target-date retirement funds or a minimal portfolio of U.S. stocks, international stocks, and bonds for most investors, with intermediate-term goals supported by bond funds. Ultimately, the strategy is not about maximizing returns but about reducing complexity and ensuring long-term financial stability through consistent saving and simple, transparent investing.
title: The benefits of keeping your investing life simple
